Hi Cruzy,Did the moderators in the HCV forum just move your post??? If so, hopefully they’ll see this and move it back; there is likely an HCV association.It took me a minute to review your previous posts in here to better understand your situation. Here’s a link to an old discussion for others to review if they’re interested:http://www.medhelp.org/posts/Hepatitis-C/Cirrosis/show/1670496#post_7621151Has your husband been diagnosed with type II diabetes along with cirrhosis? It’s not an uncommon association; his doctor can test his blood sugar and help him assess this. A burning or ‘pins and needles’ feeling in the feet is often a result of peripheral neuropathy; this in turn can be a symptom of poorly controlled, long standing diabetes. There are other causes to look at but this is likely the most common given his situation.His doctor may order blood tests and if diabetes is an issue, it can generally be controlled via diet, exercise and sometimes medication.The nosebleeds and swelling of the ankles (edema?) may be explained from his cirrhosis; nosebleeds often result from severely reduced blood platelets that manage clotting; the swelling of the ankles is common when cirrhosis is present.He needs to consult with either his primary care or liver doctor; these can all be yellow flags, and shouldn’t be ignored.Best of luck to you both,--Bill
